title: Is the Bible well written? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the sense of say Greek and Roman literature, not even close. The G/R literature was not written for encoding moral law, detailed public and private behavior, etc. While the G/R works did depict such things, there is a very distinct difference in how 'moral law' was promulgated, and lists of prohibitions or acceptable behavior was not popular. The 'play' form does not exist in either the Old or New Testament. While there is mention of 'other cultures', it is almost always in the context of a condemnation. One never finds a Herodotus, or heck even Homer's viewing both sides, perhaps with a decided bias.... of the Trojan War finale... What we get is a midget slinging a stone at a giant, blam dead... move on... that would have generated about 100 plays were it a 'greek experience', or say Samson... oh... wait... Samson would have been Hercules... and did generate a long sequence of 'heroic' works... and even some comedic works... Speaking of which The Bible is completely devoid of 'jokes'... unless of course one considers Eve to be God's second joke... One reason is perhaps that The Bible was not written for 'literature' in the least, but for 'instruction' and any literary works such as the poems attributed to David and Solomon, etc. were more for 'instruction' than actual 'literature'. We read that the Greek theater was an extension of some ancient ritual of recitation by the group, then as time passed, the 'group' reduced down to The Chorus, while one then two principle actors became the center of the performance. There is almost no equivalent literary device... perhaps with the exception of the book of Job, which could be presented as a 'theater' work. Which of course could suggest that it is a 'late' inclusion when the ancient collators of the Old Testament did in fact come in contact with more 'literate' peoples. Since the reason for the OT and by extension the NT was 'instruction/giving of law', there was for both Jews and Christians a large set of additiona texts generated on 'argument/discussion' about how to apply these laws, what sort of conduct was allowed/prohibited, under what conditions various laws held, etc. In a few words, Greek and Roman 'behavior' was regulated more by 'ethics' with a minimal set of explict 'laws', vs. a detailed set of moral laws governing all, or a large amount of 'behavior'. The later necessarily would required a large set of documents, as well as prior arguments, as exemplified by both Jewish and Christian traditions.

Let's be careful not to shoot the messenger if we don't like the message... For as a start, it helps to remember "the Bible" isn't one book and didn't have only one author. Once you realise that, many of the usual criticisms fall flat (Fallacy of composition). Nobody accuses the Library of Congress of being badly written. Second, your humble opinion has no influence on the measurable quality of the writing in its original context - disliking the content or themes in the Bible does not make any of it badly written (nor does liking them make it well written). That's judging a book by its cover. So when someone makes a judgement on the content by casting doubt on the "The Bible's" intention, questioning its agenda, or says "there are better stories", they are merely Begging the question.The reality is not everyone likes poetry, epistles, legal texts or history, least of all if they require some effort to follow. You've been to school. The fact that someone tells you something is good content does not mean you will automatically appreciate it. Whether it's Byron, Calculus, Homer or Shakespeare, much of the literature outside our usual frame of reference is often only unlocked by studying it. Especially with genres that are no longer current or have modern alternatives that are more accessible, we have to learn what to judge them by.As far as the writing  goes, you are probably reading a translation anyway, which means you are not picking up on subtleties that might have been self-evident to the original audience. Good writing assumes the skilful integration of language and culture into the text or story, and if that language and culture is foreign to your own, you are forced to grant a different mindset, suspending some of your own cultural prejudices and assumptions in order to read it as intended. (Modern readers are wary of how the Suspension of disbelief can be exploited, and we usually associate it with genres of fiction - but it is often necessary for a gracious reading of any text.)The books in their original languages may very well be of varying quality depending on author and genre, and what you compare them to. For instance, Paul might have been well educated, but he often uses a scribe or "ammanuensis" (Letters of Paul: Amanuensis) who would have been well versed in the letter-writing conventions of the time. It would be unfair of us to dismiss Paul's sincere messages (as compiled in the New Testament) because of modern prejudices against the art of first-century epistle-writing. It's not the fault of the authors if we don't appreciate the stylistic devices and requirements of their genre, or if we prefer other forms of expression (our culture is more visual than oral these days, and we prefer our messages packaged accordingly).Take the Book of Job, for example, which Lord Tennyson called "the greatest poem of ancient and modern times". It is universally regarded as a masterful example of Hebrew Wisdom literature and praised for its skilful use of language and structure by scholars of the period. Much like Ulysses and War and Peace, it is tough to appreciate the expert appraisals... but what makes armchair opinions any more authoritative?In conclusion, I don't think the average reader is in a good position to judge the literary merits of the books in the Bible. But if measured by their influence on the writers and books we generally consider to be classics in Western literature, I don't think its place in the literary corpus can be lightly discounted. See also:The Great Code: The Bible and Literature  ​Northrop Frye

The Old Testament was written primarily in Hebrew but has some Aramaic texts. The book of Daniel begins and ends in Hebrew but the bulk of the book is written in Aramaic; there is also a small portion of Aramaic in Ezra, and very small examples of Aramaic in other places. Note the use of בר (Aramaic word for son) in the following verse rather than the Hebrew word בן ‎ מַה־בְּ֭רִי וּמַֽה־בַּר־בִּטְנִ֑י וּ֜מֶה בַּר־נְדָרָֽי (Prov. 31:2 BHS) In Daniel, the change from Hebrew to Aramaic comes mid sentence, and then continues through the bulk of the book. This is the verse where the transition is made. ‎ וַֽיְדַבְּר֧וּ הַכַּשְׂדִּ֛ים לַמֶּ֖לֶךְ אֲרָמִ֑ית מַלְכָּא֙ לְעָלְמִ֣ין חֱיִ֔י אֱמַ֥ר חֶלְמָ֛א לְעַבְדַּיִךְ וּפִשְׁרָ֥א נְחַוֵּֽא (Dan. 2:4 BHS) In Hebrew: “And the Chaldeans spoke to the King [in] Aramaic” In Aramaic: “O king, live forever. Tell the dream to your servants and the interpretation we will give.” The books of the New Testament were written entirely in Greek. Some have theorized the existence of a “Q” source written in Aramaic that was the basis for the synoptic gospels i.e. Matthew, Mark, and Luke, but at this point in time no Aramaic “Q” source has been discovered. There are some minor quotes in the NT that reflect an underlying Aramaic dialog, but the text of these quotes were transliterated into Greek. Examples: καὶ ἔλεγεν· αββα ὁ πατήρ (Mk. 14:36 BGT) And he said “Abba Father” Mk. 14:36) In this example αββα is the Aramaic vocative form for father i.e. אבא And …ἐβόησεν ὁ Ἰησοῦς φωνῇ μεγάλῃ· ελωι ελωι λεμα σαβαχθανι (Mk. 15:34 BGT) Jesus cried out with a loud voice, "Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?" (Mk. 15:34) In this example, the quote is Aramaic, while most of the vocabulary is similar to the Hebrew vocabulary, the declined verb sabachthani is very different from the Hebrew azavtani. The quote comes from Ps. 22, below I have provided both the Aramaic and Hebrew versions of this verse. ‎ אלהי אלהי למנא שׁבקתני (Ps. 22:2) ‎ אֵלִ֣י אֵ֭לִי לָמָ֣ה עֲזַבְתָּ֑נִי (Ps. 22:2) These Aramaic quotes provide evidence that the language spoken by Jesus was Aramaic, but the Gospel accounts themselves were written in Greek. Even in the case of these Aramaic quotes, the Aramaic was transliterated into Greek letters in the Gospels.

Every Christian will insist any misinterpretation of the bible be put in proper context. In proper context, the bible was incredibly well written! Among other early attempts at writing, the bible was certainly very well written. Mankind’s infancy of literacy stumbled and fell over and over again. Even the original Old Testament, the Torah, was very primitive. It did not have spaces or punctuation or verb tense or capitalization/lowercase or chapter number or verb number. It was very primitive, but (again, for its time) well written. By today’s standards large parts of it are pretty much crap, and cannot be fixed as the original authors are dead. The parables and psalms hold up fairly well as individual stories. But revelations is a nonsensical fever dream. As a whole, the collection of books known as “the bible” is all over the place, split in theme and direction. Militant atheists joke it’s The Big Book of Multiple Choice. Christians themselves certainly cherry pick what verses compel them individually sect by sect. With hundreds of denominations and major splits that sometimes violently disagree with each other, the book certainly does not seem to demonstrably reflect a unified whole.

In order to answer the question of whether a given book is well-written or not, we first have to determine what its purpose might be. A novel and a car repair manual are both excellent things, and both can be very well-written (or very poorly so), but they don’t use the same styles. In fact, a car repair manual written in the style of a well-written novel, full of drama and gripping scenes and suspense. . . would actually be a very poorly written repair manual, now wouldn’t it? Either your mechanic would never get around to fixing the car, or else he’d be driven to drinking by trying to find what he needed. So, then, what’s the purpose the Bible is supposed to accomplish? Some people (a few) read it purely for literary purposes, and if that’s our motive then I’m afraid it’s very much a mixed bag. Some parts of it are quite enjoyable and well-written purely as literature, and others are not. On the other hand, some people (quite a lot) try to read it as if it were an instruction manual, and I’m afraid those people will find it to be a difficult and confusing book, because it’s not written for that purpose either. In fact, it’s partly written with the express aim of discouraging that kind of approach. The real purpose for which the Bible was written is to help the individual reader to form an intimate relationship with God. Anyone who tries to get something else out of it is trying to cut the wood at cross-purposes, and probably isn’t going to find the experience very satisfying. For that reason, it’s sometimes entertaining, sometimes instructive, sometimes difficult to understand, and sometimes even contradictory (at least on the surface). And these things are far from being flaws, because those are the kinds of things one encounters when getting to know any real person. Indeed, you can’t truly get to know anyone unless you experience a lengthy relationship with him and see many different facets of his personality. It’s only then that you can learn to love this person (or not, as the case may be). That’s why the Bible is such a lengthy book, full of so many different types of writing and so many vexing difficulties. So, given the purpose of the Book (to get to know God on a personal level, and hopefully to love Him), I’d say the Bible is very well-written indeed. It’s just not what you’d expect at first. :)

Most people who will answer this question have not studied the Bible or its history and origins. The Bible is a remarkable book, written over a period of about 1400 years by about 40 authors. It is entirely unified with a single central theme. Hundreds of Old Testament prophecies have been fulfilled already, and we see signs of more coming to pass. If you want to understand our current times - all the turmoil and unrest and rebellion, read your Bible. It’s all there, warning of what’s coming down the pike. The Bible is beautifully written and meticulously preserved. Jewish scribes have relentlessly copied manuscripts, disposing of anything that wasn’t flawless, down to an exact letter being in the exact same place on the copy, counting every word, every letter, and even throwing out mistakes as small as one dot. The differences between our current Bibles and the most ancient manuscripts are minuscule. The poetry is exquisite in the original languages. The history has been verifiable 100% by archaeological discoveries. The single theme throughout the entire book is Christ - the Redeemer of mankind. Christ, alone, fulfilled about 300 prophecies written hundreds of years before his birth. Authors that never met each other and that lived at different times wrote in complete agreement of each other. And they validate the other’s writing. The Old Testament points to the Savior of the New Testament with flawless perfection. The Bible is a powerful, life-changing book. If formed the foundation for the constitution of our nation. The reason our country is coming unraveled is because we have forsaken God and his Word. And you can be sure, without a doubt, judgment is coming and is already visible.

The Bible is extremely well written and has various genres of literature: Narrative history, poetry and prophecy. Each section of the Bible reflects the culture and customs of its day when that section was written. It is good and wise to know the culture behind each part of the Biblical text. It is not good to pull one verse out of its context to prove some predetermined belief. That is called eisegesis and leads to many misunderstandings of what the Bible does say. A better way is to read the text at hand, understanding its culture and text in the original language. Stay away from the King James text, as the meaning of many English words has changed since 1611, and new manuscripts of the ancient original languages of Hebrew, Aramaic and Koine Greek have been made in the past 200 years. It is best to read the Bible in two versions, one a literal text like the New American Standard Bible or Christian Standard Bible, and a less literal and more dynamic translation like the New International Version. Reading the Bible will be a blessing once we realize that not everything mentioned is for us now. Some things like Holy War , dietary laws, or polygamy were practiced in Old Testament times and were the norm for then, but not normative for us now. The Bible reflects the cultures in which it was written, and how God dealt with people within each culture. God still speaks through his written Word-the Bible and the Living Word Jesus Christ.

The only real way to judge ‘well-written’ is to look at the response of readers. JRR Tolkien and JK Rowling have both been accused of ‘bad writing’ by the standards of modernism popular in the 20th century. But they between them wrote nine of the most popular fourteen fiction books ever written. If you’re looking purely at literary style, in as much as that can be judged, the best-written book in the Bible might be perceived to be Job, which has an advanced vocabulary and passages of extraordinary beauty. The worst-written, in the sense that the grammar is at times ‘unexpected’ is Revelation. And yet Revelation has been one of the most significant inspirations in Western Art for 1500 years, and has had a dramatic impact on thought and language. Was William Blake a great writer, or just a bit weird? Was James Joyce a great writer, or just odd? Both of them are in the canon of literary English. Certainly William Tyndale and Miles Coverdale’s translation of the Bible, even in the slightly watered-down form of the 1611 King James Version, has established itself as one of the most important works in English literature, and is cited by many as the single most important work in English. The Bible is the world’s best-selling book, and it is every year. It has been translated into vastly more languages than any other book, and it exists in English translation in more versions than any other book. It is the most cited book in human history. You could reasonably argue that the Bible is the standard by which ‘well-written’ should be judged, since no other book can come close to it. Even in terms of plot, the producer of the long-running (and often most-popular) British soap opera Eastenders maintained that all of the storylines were taken directly from the Bible.[1] Footnotes[1] Would you Adam and Eve it? Absolutely. The Bible is majestic. It is truly brilliant and bears the marks of divinity down to even the structural level. There are story arcs that resolve after millennia. There are allusions that show up in the strangest places, with stuff you would only catch on your 8th read-through of the whole Bible, but not the 7th, and so on. The composition of books are so thoughtful that serious interpretive problems can arrive merely from underestimating the care put into the book. That’s just reading English translations. If you can read the original languages you can see all kinds of clever wordplay and masterfully fluid poetry. Just reading contemporary books to the Old Testament, like the Epic of Gilgamesh, or the Enuma Elis demonstrates enough familiarity to show they had some common literary relationships, but the Bible is just better.

Different parts are beautiful poetry, magnificent prose and simply turgid writing, as you would expect from so many authors writing at different times and with different skills and agendas. This is seen very clearly in the Book of Isaiah, where Isaiah son of Amoz (chapters 1–39) uses a limited vocabulary, but to good effect, while Second Isaiah (chapters 40–55) and Third Isaiah (chapters 56–66) both have a much larger vocabulary and more lyrical style.
